<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_read_map_attr:
```c
static int metal_uio_read_map_attr(struct linux_device *ldev,
				   unsigned int index,
				   const char *name,
				   unsigned long *value)
{
	const char *cls = ldev->cls_path;
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	char path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX];
	int result;

	result = snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/maps/map%u/%s", cls, index, name);
	if (result >= (int)sizeof(path))
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	attr = sysfs_open_attribute(path);
	if (!attr || sysfs_read_attribute(attr) != 0) {
		sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
		return -errno;
	}

	*value = strtoul(attr->value, NULL, 0);

	sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: Fragments not listed were reviewed and considered not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: - The parameter 'const char *name' is already const-qualified. - The 'unsigned long *value' pointer is used to return a result (written to), so it cannot be const. - 'char path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX]' is a mutable buffer passed to snprintf and must be modifiable. - Local scalar variables (result, errno handling) and calls to snprintf do not involve pointer-to-object const-qualification concerns. Therefore only the listed pointer-related fragments need investigation for whether they could/should point to const-qualified types.
